awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of medical image analysis is to extract quantitative information from images. Image registration is a key image analysis technique to estimate spatial correspondences between images. However, while good results have been obtained, registration methods are typically slow, specifically, when complex deformations are to be captured. This limits the utility of these algorithms (i) for very large-scale imaging studies, (ii) as component algorithms of more advanced analysis algorithms, and (iii) for applications which would benefit from rapid solutions, for example, to facilitate user interaction. Furthermore, registration methods are typically ill-adapted to given tasks, as, for mathematical convenience only, approaches use simple elastic or fluid models from physics. This lack of task-specificity impairs achievable registration accuracy, even for state-of-the-art algorithms.

Intellectual Merit: This project will therefore further develop, invent, and investigate fast analysis approaches based on replacing costly numerical optimizations by fast, approximate, learned regression models for image registration. Using such learned regression models will facilitate analysis approaches which were previously not easily possible due to computational constraints (for example, general large-scale image analysis or geodesic regression approaches for images which use deformation distances to measure model residuals}. This project will also explore regression models for task-specific registrations (for example, for longitudinal data) and will therefore open up the possibility to achieve registration accuracies beyond the current state-of-the-art. The project results will have immediate impact on current brain imaging studies and will form the basis for advanced analyses of brain and general imaging data.

Broader Impact: While the proposed methods are motivated by the analysis of brain images, the invented methods will have more general applicability, e.g., to analyze abdominal, lung, or even non-medical image data. For flexibility and to assure utility of the approaches in other application domains, all methods will be made available to the community in open-source form. This will allow others to adapt approaches, to replicate results, and to create customized analysis approaches. To ease interpretability of results we will provide simple visualizations and approaches for uncertainty quantification, thereby facilitating communication between computational analysts and domain experts.

por.por_cntn:
This project developed fast machine learning models for medical image analysis. In particular, it developed deep learning models for key medical image analysis tasks related to image segmentation and image registration. Image segmentation is the task of automatically extracting semantically meaningful image regions and the goal of image registration is to spatially align images, i.e., to find which point in one image most likely corresponds to a specific point in another image. The work in this project resulted in ultra-fast image registration approaches which enable aligning large image volumes in a matter of seconds. This allowed for example to efficiently compute registrations for large-scale imaging studies. Going forward such fast image registration approaches are expected to be highly beneficial when real-time or interactive registrations are required or desired. Building on the success of these registration models, this project also developed new approaches for efficient atlas-building (i.e., how to estimate average images that are good representatives of a population of images) and atlas-based segmentation. In atlas-based segmentation segmentations are obtained by registering several segmented images to an image which still needs to be segmented. Once registered one can then obtain a segmentation by a simple plurality vote among the registered segmentations, which is a form of label fusion. To improve upon this label fusion approach this project developed approaches to predict which registered segmentations are locally trustworthy and which ones are not. This in turn allowed focusing on the most trustworthy predictions to make the final segmentation decision and in consequence improved segmentation results. The project also explored trustworthiness of general segmentation results obtained, for example, by a deep network. For such segmentation methods one generally obtains continuous label outputs that, however, usually do not correspond to proper label probabilities. Hence, this project developed an approach for post-hoc local calibration, which can adjust continuous label outputs to transform them into proper label probabilities that can then be used to assess segmentation confidence. The project also developed clustering approaches that allow incorporating side information that can guide clustering results and that estimate trajectories that best fit the data. All the approaches developed as part of this project were motivated by medical driving problems. However, the resulting approaches are general and are expected to be useful for many other analysis tasks for images and beyond.



 

 


Last Modified: 10/20/2022
Modified by: Marc Niethammer
por.por_txt_cntn:
This project developed fast machine learning models for medical image analysis. In particular, it developed deep learning models for key medical image analysis tasks related to image segmentation and image registration. Image segmentation is the task of automatically extracting semantically meaningful image regions and the goal of image registration is to spatially align images, i.e., to find which point in one image most likely corresponds to a specific point in another image. The work in this project resulted in ultra-fast image registration approaches which enable aligning large image volumes in a matter of seconds. This allowed for example to efficiently compute registrations for large-scale imaging studies. Going forward such fast image registration approaches are expected to be highly beneficial when real-time or interactive registrations are required or desired. Building on the success of these registration models, this project also developed new approaches for efficient atlas-building (i.e., how to estimate average images that are good representatives of a population of images) and atlas-based segmentation. In atlas-based segmentation segmentations are obtained by registering several segmented images to an image which still needs to be segmented. Once registered one can then obtain a segmentation by a simple plurality vote among the registered segmentations, which is a form of label fusion. To improve upon this label fusion approach this project developed approaches to predict which registered segmentations are locally trustworthy and which ones are not. This in turn allowed focusing on the most trustworthy predictions to make the final segmentation decision and in consequence improved segmentation results. The project also explored trustworthiness of general segmentation results obtained, for example, by a deep network. For such segmentation methods one generally obtains continuous label outputs that, however, usually do not correspond to proper label probabilities. Hence, this project developed an approach for post-hoc local calibration, which can adjust continuous label outputs to transform them into proper label probabilities that can then be used to assess segmentation confidence. The project also developed clustering approaches that allow incorporating side information that can guide clustering results and that estimate trajectories that best fit the data. All the approaches developed as part of this project were motivated by medical driving problems. However, the resulting approaches are general and are expected to be useful for many other analysis tasks for images and beyond.
